div.p: Black Student Union representa­ tives who met with University Pres­ ident Wilson H. Elkins Monday con­ cerning their 14 demands said yes­ terday they were not satisfied with the discussion.
Foster Hall, BSU treasurer and one of three members who met with Elkins, said they will seek another meeting with Elkins tomorrow.
"If we don’t see any action on our demands, we will take our own ac­ tion,” he added.
The other two representatives who met with Elkins were BSU Pres­ ident Terance Cooper and Chrlss Young.

During the 45-minute meeting, all but three of the demands were dis­ cussed, Hall said. The original list of demands had been presented Fri­ day to Walter B. Waetjen, vice pres­ ident for administrative affairs.
Elkins began by saying the demand that he and other members of the administration resign was non-neg­ otiable, according to Hall.
Some of the demands were be­ yond his authority, Elkins added ac­ cording to a University spokesman, and if he resigned he ‘‘wouldn’t be in a position to respond” at all.
The president said he had no auth­ ority to Intervene in the Maryland State College Issue until the school comes under University jurisdiction July 1.
BSU had demanded that the 181 students arrested at the college rec­ently not be penalized for their buil­ ding occupation action and that col­ lege President John T. Williams be fired.
Elkins also said he had no in­ fluence with the state to push for pay raises for campus classified workers, as BSU had demanded, Hall said.

The president answered the demand for a change In the black studies pro­ gram to Include black community-ori­ ented projects by saying the Uni­ versity "does not have the capabil­ ity or presently the faculty to ex­ tend itself” Into the community.
Hall noted that the increase in funds for black studies, which Elkins said would be proportional to the Increase In the entire budget, was not accept­ able to BSU members.
To the demand that classes be pro­ vided for residents of nearby Lake­ land, Elkins responded that classes are both possible and probable.
He said he would talk to faculty about It and requested BSU to draw up a plan for using the adult edu­ cation center for the classes.
Hall said that plan and another one for including the children of campus service workers in the Uni­ versity kindergarten program would be submitted today.
Elkins had Informed the BSU rep­ resentatives at the meeting that the kindergarten was open to all campus employes.
The demand that recruiting of black students and faculty be stepped up was answered with a statement by El­ kins that the present program was sufficient.
Hall contended, however, that the number of blacks has not Increased substantially, although he said he would not have the exact figures un­ til today.

one of the demands, that amnesty be granted to three black students who were arested after a fight In College Park recently, had been turned over to J. Winston Martin, vice president for student affairs, for Investigation shortly after the Incident happened.
Elkins noted that the University does not have jurisdiction In such off-campus cases.
Hall mentioned, however, that he has not heard from Martin since sometime before Easter vacation.
Regarding another demand, Elkins said it would be “illegal” to reor­ ganize the University structure to place control in the hands of students, faculty and chosen administrators.

He said, however, that as soon as a human relations director is appoin­ ted, students could take their ideas for change to him. The director will be the vice chancellor, Elkins said. Both the director and the chancel­ lor have yet to be appointed.

The demand for free legal counsel for black students “made to suffer as a result of their political activ­ ity” was satisfied when Student Gov­ ernment President Stu Robinson of­ fered the use of the SGA legal aid fund, which does not come from state funds, Hall said.
